author: By Dani Blum and Nicole Stock
title: A Comprehensive Guide to Birth Control
description: From condoms to IUDs to tubal ligation, experts weigh in on how to assess and obtain birth control options.
content: Over the past few decades, the number of birth control methods available in the United States has grown sharply. Women today are faced with a dizzying array of new pills, implants, gels and patches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Andrea Pirlo Is Timeless
description: With elite soccer increasingly driven by coaches and systems, Pirlo feels as if he belongs to another era. But can a classic ever go out of style?
content: Officially, whenever Andrea Pirlo has watched soccer over the course of the last year or so, it has been for work, rather than merely for pleasure. It might be almost a year since his first foray into management was ended, abruptly and unceremoniously, by Juventus, but being a manager is less a job and more a lifestyle choice, like being a monk, or a double agent. It cannot be switched off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Pelosi Increases Pay Scale for House Staff, Setting a New Wage Floor
description: The speaker said staff aides would earn at least $45,000 annually and boosted the pay cap to $203,700. She also set a vote on a bill to protect those who unionize.
content: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California on Friday announced she was instituting a higher pay scale for House staff, moving for the first time to set a floor on annual wages and boosting the maximum salary in a bid to improve working conditions on Capitol Hill and retain congressional staff.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 6, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, May 6, 2022.
content: An article on Thursday about rising violence by separatists in Pakistan misstated the timing of an assault on the Pakistan Stock Exchange by Baluchistan Liberation Army militants. The stock exchange assault in Karachi occurred in 2020, not the year after the group’s 2018 attack on the Chinese consulate there. The article also misstated part of the name of an Islamabad-based think tank. It is the Pak Institute for Peace Studies, not the Pak Institute of Peace Studies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Black Star’s First Album in 24 Years Arrives, and 11 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Sharon Van Etten, Carly Rae Jepsen, 070 Shake and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
title: How Long Can the Hot Job Market Continue?
description: The Federal Reserve’s efforts to slow inflation might hit hiring as well.
content: This morning, the Labor Department will report how many jobs employers added to their payrolls in April. Economists believe it was another solid month of growth. Those surveyed by Bloomberg forecast an addition of 380,000 workers. The unemployment rate is expected to decline slightly to 3.5 percent, returning to its level in February 2020, which was the lowest rate since 1969.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Jack Harlow Knows What He Wants. And Where He Stands.
description: On the heels of his first solo No. 1 hit, the 24-year-old rapper is releasing “Come Home the Kids Miss You,” an album that appeals to the vastly different corners of his fan base.
content: ATLANTA — Last June, on the red carpet at the BET Awards, Jack Harlow finished up an interview and noticed that the rapper Saweetie was nearby. He had appeared on a remix of her hit “Tap In,” but the two hadn’t yet met in person. And so he strolled up, tilted his body slightly in her direction, smoothly extended his hand and said hello.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Life in a Minnesota ‘Fishbowl’: Water Everywhere, Except Inside Town
description: When the Red River floods near Oslo, Minn., which happens a lot, residents are stuck within the city limits. But a truce with nature keeps the water away from their homes.
content: OSLO, Minn. — Every year or three, when the river rises and the roads vanish, a couple of hundred Minnesotans become island dwellers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Greenblatt
title: ‘To Be or Not to Be’: Is It the Question or the Point?
description: At the Metropolitan Opera, Brett Dean and Matthew Jocelyn’s adaptation of “Hamlet” nods to different, surprising versions of Shakespeare’s text.
content: “Hamlet” is our culture’s supreme emblem of a great artist’s freedom to create something radically new. Shakespeare found a way to represent the inner life as it had never been represented before: the pressure of compulsive, involuntary memories; the haunting presence of a dead father; a son’s angst in the wake of his mother’s remarriage; the suicidal thoughts of a young person forced to make impossible choices in a corrupt world. It is here, if anywhere, that Jorge Luis Borges could claim with a straight face that Shakespeare was God.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hong
title: Sweetness and Blight: Shattering the Unicorn Myth
description: The first book in A.F. Steadman’s middle grade fantasy series will enthrall young readers who are ready to put away childish things.
content: SKANDAR AND THE UNICORN THIEFBy A.F. Steadman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: The U.N. Security Council makes its first unanimous statement on the war, with Russia’s approval.
description: More than two months into the fighting, the body was able to agree on language that got past Russia’s veto power.
content: In its first unanimous action on the Ukraine war, the United Nations Security Council on Friday adopted a statement expressing “deep concern” and “strong support” for diplomatic efforts by the U.N. secretary general to find a peaceful solution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Entrada Kelly
title: A New Novel From the Author of ‘When You Trap a Tiger’
description: In Tae Keller’s “Jennifer Chan Is Not Alone,” believing in aliens is less scary than fitting in.
content: JENNIFER CHAN IS NOT ALONEBy Tae Keller
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg
title: Her Job Is a Walk in the Park
description: For this Park Slope dog walker, it’s all about community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Elemia
title: In the Philippines, a Flourishing Ecosystem for Political Lies
description: Supporters of Ferdinand Marcos Jr. are using live video to spread misinformation on social media. Voters have become inured to the situation, researchers fear.
content: CAVITE, Philippines — Arnel Agravante, a YouTuber in the Philippines, told his followers last October that he knew how Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the presidential front-runner and his candidate of choice, had become wealthy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Peed
title: Stories of Survival, in the Wilds, in Cities and at Home
description: Three new story collections explore the vagaries of daily struggles.
content: Leigh Newman finds in her native Alaska all that she needs to survey themes of betrayal and isolation, of desertion and disintegration (physical, psychological, spiritual). In her story collection NOBODY GETS OUT ALIVE (Scribner, 278 pp., $26), the heroic loom of the mountains — “contented giants, their faces slashed with ice and moonlight” — gives way to the splintered souls — “ailing, bewildered, clouded with regret” — who prowl the foothills below. A pair of sisters, crushed by their parents’ divorce and alcoholism, turn their pain on each other, riding a “diseased seesaw” of commitment and rejection. In “Slide and Glide,” a man attempts to save his marriage by compelling his family to undertake a risky wilderness trek, seeking “something more than love — trust.” And a California newcomer, convinced of the palliative “dazzle of Alaska,” discovers that “nothing here is fixed, nothing is any better. Where is there left to go, except out of your mind?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Foo
title: I Cherish My Grief for the Mother I Never Expected to Have
description: There is grief that strangles you and grief that holds you.
content: I usually delete the Instagram app on my phone on Mother’s Day. I already know what the posts will be: pictures of my friends as babies, sitting on their mothers’ laps, photos of them toasting their mothers at brunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Labor regulators find merit in accusations by unions at Amazon and Starbucks.
description: Workers had accused the companies of unlawful behavior during recent union campaigns.
content: In a sign that federal labor officials are closely scrutinizing management behavior during union campaigns, the National Labor Relations Board said Friday that it had found merit in accusations that Amazon and Starbucks had violated labor law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: When Shopping for Funeral Services, Be Wary
description: Experts say that when people are making decisions at such a stressful time, they are vulnerable to overpaying. “It’s a good day for the criminal or the dishonest salesperson.”
content: People shopping for funeral or cremation services may be particularly vulnerable to overpaying or being swindled, which is why experts say it’s important to be cautious when making those decisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Greta Lee Is Still a Pool Shark
description: The actress, who stars in “Russian Doll,” visits her favorite Koreatown haunts.
content: “I like to find the most impossible shot and then get really disappointed when it doesn’t happen,” the actress Greta Lee said, leaning over a billiards table in the Koreatown section of Manhattan. “I don’t know what that says about me.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: What were people voting for?
description: Britons voted on Thursday to select thousands of representatives in scores of local municipalities, mostly council members who oversee functions like filling potholes, collecting trash and issuing construction permits.
content: Britons voted on Thursday to select thousands of representatives in scores of local municipalities, mostly council members who oversee functions like filling potholes, collecting trash and issuing construction permits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Are There Any Alternative Prom Dresses?
description: A reader asks for help finding her daughter the right frock for the night.
content: Not with “Euphoria.” That much-buzzed-about award-winning teen streaming drama has given rise to an entire fashion subset on TikTok largely featuring what seems to be efforts to wear the tiniest, most body-conscious amount of clothing possible. And not with “The Breakfast Club,” the 1985 John Hughes film in which Molly Ringwald canonized the prom queen stereotype.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Inflation concerns are at the center of an Ohio Senate contest.
description: The race between Representative Tim Ryan and J.D. Vance will require them to win over establishment Republicans and working-class voters.
content: Inflation and high gas, food and energy prices were among the top issues animating voters in this week’s primary contests in Ohio, where an intense general election battle for a Senate seat is now unfolding between Representative Tim Ryan and J.D. Vance, the author and investor. The race is expected to largely center on winning over establishment Republicans and working-class voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: peculiar
description: This word has appeared in 307 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word peculiar has appeared in 307 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 1 in “Remembrance of Bookstores Past” by Tina Jordan and Erica Ackerberg:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Rents May Rise as Much as 6 Percent for Some N.Y.C. Tenants
description: In a preliminary vote, the Rent Guidelines Board approved the biggest increases in nearly a decade.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. We’ll look at rent increases that are looming for more than two million New Yorkers. We’ll also preview the new look for the Times Square tower where the ball drops on New Year’s Eve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise and Noam Scheiber
title: Amazon Abruptly Fires Senior Managers Tied to Unionized Warehouse
description: Company officials said the terminations were the result of an internal review, while the fired managers saw it as a response to the recent union victory.
content: After Amazon employees at a massive warehouse on Staten Island scored an upset union victory last month, it turned the union’s leaders into celebrities, sent shock waves through the broader labor movement and prompted politicians around the country to rally behind Amazon workers. Now it also appears to have created fallout within Amazon’s management ranks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Has Shanghai Been Xinjianged?
description: Shanghai used to be the glamorous China, while Xinjiang was the dark China. Now both are casualties of authoritarian excess.
content: Shanghai and Xinjiang used to be the two sides of the China coin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: A Landlord ‘Underestimated’ His Tenants. Now They Could Own the Building.
description: When a new landlord bought their building in the Bronx and threatened to raise rents and kick them out, tenants banded together. They never expected how far they might get: the chance to buy their apartments for $2,500 each.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Behind Bad Bunny’s Summery Surprise, ‘Un Verano Sin Ti’
description: “I’ve made it clear to people that I’m never going to make a record that’s the same as another,” the pop star said. His fourth album was inspired by a spectrum of Caribbean music.
content: Most pop stars would move heaven and earth to attend the Met Gala. But for Bad Bunny, one of music’s most idiosyncratic figures, it’s just another Monday night. “Obviously I’m happy that they invited me,” he said, twirling from side to side in a high leather swivel chair at New York’s venerated Electric Lady Studios about 48 hours before the exclusive fashion fête. “I know that day is going to be an exciting thing,” he continued. “But I’m working a lot this week!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Abigail Varney
title: How the King of Rock ’n’ Roll Still Makes Australia Sing
description: Elvis never played a concert “down under,” but that hasn’t stopped tens of thousands of Australians from making him their own at an annual festival.
content: PARKES, Australia — The Elvis Presley from Japan bowed with quiet respect. Then he tore into a rendition of “Burning Love” that sounded straight out of Memphis, and that definitely stretched the crotch of his blue jumpsuit to the limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: W.N.B.A. Season Preview: New Talent Is Here, but an Absence Looms
description: The league will honor Phoenix Mercury center Brittney Griner, who remains in custody in Russia, as its new season begins Friday.
content: The longest W.N.B.A. season in league history will begin on Friday. For the first time, teams will each play 36 regular-season games as the next step in the league’s plan for incremental growth — a plan stifled for the past two seasons by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Chanel in Monaco: ‘Our Town’ by Way of the Grimaldis and the Go-Go’s
description: Destination shows return with Virginie Viard’s cruise collection, while Celine makes a movie.
content: The Met Gala, in full ostentatious, crowd-pleasing costumery, returned this week, flooding the fashion news cycle. Ditto the hordes of fans jostling outside of fashion shows, and the audience scrums inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David L. Kirp
title: Pre-K Is Powerful if Done Right. Here’s How.
description: Low-quality pre-K programs can be worse than useless. High-quality ones can change lives.
content: The Build Back Better plan, President Biden’s ambitious social spending bill, is dead in the water. However, a cornerstone of the bill — a historic commitment to early education and child care, offering universal access to prekindergarten for 3- and 4-year-olds — still might have a chance of passage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Seeking Spring Comfort? Try This Buttery, Vegetable-Topped Polenta.
description: Verdant asparagus, peas and shallots top this light yet comforting meal from Melissa Clark.
content: Comfort food can take different forms. At its most heartfelt, it’s those childhood tastes that resonate emotionally: a pan of noodle kugel, a chicken foot straight out of my grandmother’s soup pot, a buttered slice of my father’s warm anadama bread. They may not be comforting to everyone, but, to me, they’re as soothing as a purring cat curled up in my lap (also not comforting for everyone).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Why Republicans Are So Angry About the Supreme Court Leak
description: Whatever legitimacy the court had retained was sacrificed in the drive to build the majority that seems poised to overturn Roe v. Wade.
content: The country is divided. There are those Americans furious that the Supreme Court is soon to take away the right to have an abortion. And there are those Americans furious that someone leaked that the Supreme Court was soon to take away the right to have an abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Layla Kinjawi Faraj
title: My Plea for a Sixth Love Language
description: The winner of our college essay contest explores how for her Syrian family, scattered by war, a WhatsApp group chat — rife with silly videos and often regrettable photos — is everything.
content: According to writer Gary Chapman, there are five love languages: words of affirmation, quality time, receiving gifts, physical touch and acts of service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Johnnie A. Jones Sr. Dies at 102; a Civil Rights Lawyer Early On
description: In 1953, he represented defendants in the Baton Rouge bus boycott, a model for later activism, after returning from World War II as a wounded veteran of D-Day.
content: Two weeks after Johnnie A. Jones Sr. graduated from law school in 1953, he was thrust into a case that would set a template for the civil rights movement, and for his own legal career: He was recruited to help represent people who had been arrested during a bus boycott in Baton Rouge, the Louisiana capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: How Do You Silence Your Inner Critic?
description: Do you have a voice in your head telling you that you’re not good enough?
content: Do you ever hear a voice in your head telling you that you are no good or that says to give up what you’re doing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan and Sharon Otterman
title: Worries about the strain on health care grow in the U.S. as hot spots spread and hospitalizations rise.
description: The C.D.C. is also keeping a close eye on the nature of hospitalizations.
content: When the coronavirus was in retreat across the United States in late February, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued new recommendations that veered away from depending on the number of new cases in a community to determine the need for pandemic safety measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: First, a Circuitous Courtship. Then a ‘Crazy’ Wedding Ceremony.
description: Susan Alavi and Evan Schaeffer, who first met in high school, broke up several times before finally making their relationship work.
content: Susan Hampton Alavi and Evan Michael Schaeffer dated in fits and starts for almost a decade before settling into a steady relationship, much of which was long distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Syjuco
title: The Man Who Could Ruin the Philippines Forever
description: We Filipinos were once proud of our democracy. The coming elections could see its end.
content: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., known as Bongbong, was convicted of tax evasion. He also lied about his academic degree, according to Oxford University. Victims of his father’s brutal regime — which lasted for 20 years until his ouster in 1986 — accuse the younger Mr. Marcos of whitewashing history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Suddenly, Rangers Look More Like Their Regular-Season Selves
description: After losing Game 1 in triple overtime, New York rebounded to a 5-2 win over the Penguins to tie their N.H.L. playoff series at one game apiece.
content: The New York Rangers and Pittsburgh Penguins would have been hard-pressed to repeat the drama of the opening game of their playoff series, which the Penguins won in triple overtime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Jack Ewing
title: Why Musk’s Twitter Bid Has Shaken Tesla Investors
description: The chief executive’s debt load, his divided attention and Twitter’s own challenges could all take a toll on his electric-car company.
content: Elon Musk’s deal for Twitter has features that make it risky, including billions of dollars of personal debt. If it goes wrong, it could burn Tesla shareholders and strain Twitter’s financial health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Divided Unionists have left an opening for Sinn Fein in Northern Ireland.
description: The Irish nationalist party, Sinn Fein, was widely expected to win the most seats in elections for the Northern Ireland legislature on Thursday, an outcome that would represent an extraordinary coming-of-age for a political party that many still associate with years of paramilitary violence.
content: The Irish nationalist party, Sinn Fein, was widely expected to win the most seats in elections for the Northern Ireland legislature on Thursday, an outcome that would represent an extraordinary coming-of-age for a political party that many still associate with years of paramilitary violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Teen Mother. Housekeeper. Activist. Vice President?
description: Francia Márquez could soon be Colombia’s first Black vice president, and she has cracked open a discussion about race and class in a manner rarely seen in national politics.
content: CALI, Colombia — In the streets of Cali, a cradle of Colombian culture and protest, a crowd stretched for blocks, flying white campaign flags and wearing T-shirts that read “the people will not surrender!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Maria Marcus, Public Interest Lawyer and Mentor, Dies at 88
description: She argued before the Supreme Court six times representing New York State, took on civil rights cases for the N.A.A.C.P. and taught at Fordham for decades.
content: Maria Marcus, a law professor who as a public interest lawyer defended civil rights in the South and successfully argued six cases before the United States Supreme Court representing New York State, in one instance winning unemployment benefits for striking workers, died on April 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Job Growth Shows Continuing Vigor of U.S. Economy
description: The Labor Department reported a gain of 428,000 jobs in April, along with a 5.5 percent increase in average hourly earnings from a year earlier.
content: The U.S. economic rebound from the pandemic’s devastation held strong in April with another month of solid job growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Bill Classifying Abortion as Homicide Is Advanced by Louisiana Lawmakers
description: The proposal threatens to prosecute women who end a pregnancy, a possible new frontier in the abortion debate as the Supreme Court appears inclined to overturn Roe v. Wade.
content: The State Legislature in Louisiana advanced a proposal this week that would classify abortion as homicide, going further than anti-abortion measures in other states by making it possible for prosecutors to bring criminal cases against women who end a pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: You’re Cleaning All Wrong
description: A science-based guide for fellow germaphobes.
content: One of my first memories is the pungent smell of rubbing alcohol. Every evening, my mother sprayed the kitchen sink and counters with isopropyl alcohol to disinfect them. And no wonder: She’d cared for me for months when I caught a nasty salmonella infection as a toddler. Bacteria were her nemesis. “I became a real nut about it,” she admitted recently. “I really became a germaphobe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Goodwill Sold a Bust for $34.99. It’s an Ancient Roman Relic.
description: Its 2,000-year journey to Texas remains a mystery, but the buyer is returning it to the German state of Bavaria, its pre-World War II home.
content: Laura Young was browsing through a Goodwill store in Austin, Texas, in 2018 when she found a bust for sale. It was resting on the floor, under a table, and had a yellow price tag slapped on its cheek: $34.99. She bought it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: How a Comic Book Collector Spends His Sundays
description: Vincent Zurzolo, comics expert, is also into wellness. He meditates, eats a high-protein diet, works out and moisturizes.
content: When Vincent Zurzolo was 5, he would beg his mother for 10 cents so he could buy comic books at the luncheonette and candy store near his home in Rockaway Beach, Queens. “My first comic book was Ghost Rider No. 19, 1976, Mr. Zurzolo said. “By 15 I started buying and selling them with a friend. I become known as the comic book kid in my school.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Into the Woods’ Review: Some Enchanted Evening
description: Sara Bareilles and Neil Patrick Harris lead a starry Encores! revival of Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine’s sweet-sour musical.
content: For nearly three decades, the Encores! concert series at New York City Center has upheld a specific mission — excavating the hidden gems of American musical theater, burnishing them to a fully orchestrated shine. Which makes the fractured fairy tales of “Into the Woods,” Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine’s sweet-sour 1986 musical, a peculiar choice. (Let’s just say that when Rob Marshall has directed a star-crammed film version of a show within the last decade, it is no longer a hidden gem.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Tesla will cover transportation costs for employee abortions.
description: The company recently moved to Texas, which is home to some of the country’s most restrictive abortion laws.
content: Tesla is covering transportation costs for employees to get out-of-state abortions, joining the likes of Citigroup and Yelp as various state regulations have limited access to abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Oil Profits Soar, but the Industry’s Path Forward Remains Uncertain
description: Here are four climate takeaways from a dramatic turnaround — a year after a surge of shareholder activism in the industry, as well as a remarkable court ruling against Shell.
content: The war in Ukraine has been good for oil companies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: One Village at a Time: The Grinding Artillery War in Ukraine
description: The advances by the Ukrainian army in the north have been modest, but they are emblematic of both sides’ strategy: maneuvering artillery to gain territory.
content: RUSKA LOZOVA, Ukraine — The Ukrainian major had a few tasks to complete as he made the rounds along his army battalion’s front line. One platoon commander needed anti-tank weapons. Another wanted to show off a new line of trenches that his forces had dug following a recent Ukrainian advance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: A Light and Fresh Menu That Meets the Moment
description: A tangy beet soup, rich wild salmon and an elegant cherry compote from David Tanis round out a bright meal made for May.
content: The spring awakening is upon us. At the market, asparagus is showing up, along with leafy young turnips and the first peas. But even beets can be springy when given a chance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: Market Pain Isn’t Over, but You Will Get Through This
description: Head-spinning volatility in financial markets isn’t all that puzzling when you consider the problems the Federal Reserve is grappling with, our columnist says.
content: On Wednesday, the S&P 500 stock index jumped 3 percent, as though all was right with the world. On Thursday, stocks collapsed, with the tech-heavy Nasdaq index plunging 5 percent as though the end of times was in sight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: The Deeper Meaning of Elvis in Australia
description: I went to the Parkes Elvis Festival thinking I’d learn something about what America used to be. I left thinking more about Australia.
content: The first time I learned to love Elvis Presley, I was in my early 20s, and visiting Graceland during a cross-country trip with a few friends. I remember watching videos of his concerts in a dark theater there and being amazed at his energy and talent. Next, there was Baghdad Elvis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Marie Kondo Is Here to Tidy Up Your Pandemic Clutter — if You Want To
description: The past two years have changed the way we live in our homes. Are we ready to return to a spartan existence, or is our new stuff what sparks joy now?
content: Marie Kondo has big plans for us to tidy not just our homes, but our entire lives. But is a country that has spent the past two years on a relentless shopping spree, filling homes with Peloton bikes, fire pits and bread machines, still in the mood for Ms. Kondo’s minimalist brand of tidying?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Officials Are on the Defensive as High Inflation Lingers
description: Critics have accused the Federal Reserve of not reacting quickly enough to tame rising prices. On Friday, a Fed governor explained why it took so long.
content: Christopher Waller, a governor at the Federal Reserve, faced an uncomfortable task on Friday night: He delivered remarks at a conference packed with leading academic economists titled, suggestively, “How Monetary Policy Got Behind the Curve and How to Get Back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Ex-Officer Gets 5 Years for Assaulting Woman With Dementia During Arrest
description: Austin Hopp pleaded guilty in March to second-degree assault for throwing to the ground and injuring Karen Garner, 73 at the time, during an arrest on suspicion of shoplifting in Colorado.
content: A former Colorado police officer was sentenced to five years in prison and three years of parole on Thursday for assaulting a 73-year-old woman with dementia while arresting her on suspicion of shoplifting around $14 worth of items from a Walmart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: The Ocean’s Biggest Garbage Pile Is Full of Floating Life
description: Researchers found that small sea creatures exist in equal number with pieces of plastic in parts of the Great Pacific Garbage Patch, which could have implications for cleaning up ocean pollution.
content: In 2019, the French swimmer Benoit Lecomte swam over 300 nautical miles through the Great Pacific Garbage Patch to raise awareness about marine plastic pollution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Marjan Neshat on Her ‘Kind of Miraculous Season’ Onstage
description: Now starring in “Wish You Were Here,” the Iranian-born actress has made her mark in three works by playwrights of Middle Eastern descent.
content: The playwrights Sylvia Khoury and Sanaz Toossi drank a toast recently to the radiant actor they have shared this season across three major Off Broadway productions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Stocks drop again as investors weigh the latest jobs report.
description: Investors are on edge amid uncertainty about the fate of the economy.
content: Stocks fell on Friday, ending a wild week that saw the market rally and then collapse in rapid succession, as investors considered the implications of the latest update on the U.S. job market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Marx
title: Building a Relationship on Laughter, and Monthly Meetings
description: Julie Fogel and Matt Singley met at a Chicago sports bar in 2018 and immediately hit it off. “We had the same sense of humor,” she said.
content: Though Julie Beth Fogel is more than a foot shorter than Matt Paul Singley, she immediately realized the two were eye to eye on humor when they met at the now-closed Chicago sports bar Bottled Blonde in December 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Abortion is already starting to reshape these notable midterm campaigns.
description: In Pennsylvania, Georgia and beyond, the prospective fall of Roe v. Wade hangs over key primary and general elections.
content: There was never any doubt that an impending Supreme Court decision on abortion, expected over the summer, would have an outsize effect on the midterm campaigns this year. The issue just wasn’t expected to upend the races so soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Gold
title: Voters Have Finally Punished Boris Johnson
description: If Mr. Johnson does not go, and soon, it will be hard to avoid the conclusion that we have crossed a Rubicon from which it will be difficult to return.
content: CORNWALL, England — Lots of people predicted that Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s administration would be a bin fire, but I don’t think anyone expected it to be quite so surreal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: No Second Chances
description: Aaron Ullman makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — When you make your New York Times Crossword debut, you have only one shot to make your first impression — no second chances. Today’s constructor, Aaron Ullman, nails that shot, with this beautiful themeless grid featuring two intersecting staircases of entries, lively fill and outstanding clues. Fortunately, when you’re solving someone’s New York Times Crossword debut, you have as many second chances as you need to figure out a particularly tricky clue. (This isn’t the case, I suppose, if you are solving in pen — and I don’t recommend that!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Storm
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, inspired by this image.
content: Imagine an idyllic coastal town. What could go wrong? Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include an Argentine heist thriller, a whimsical Palestinian romance, a German period drama and more.
content: In January 2006, a band of robbers in Argentina pulled off a bank theft of such astonishing scale and technical precision that it came to be known as “the heist of the century.” Full of intrigue, spectacle and outsize personalities, their story is made for the movies, and Ariel Winograd’s stylish feature — co-written with the mastermind of the heist himself, Fernando Araujo — milks it to the fullest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Ada Limón Makes Poems for a Living
description: On tour for her sixth book, Limón talks about how poetry, in the end, is “just telling somebody something.” Listen to her read some of her work.
content: Ada Limón is a professional poet: She does not support herself with a teaching position, has no day job or independent wealth. She is a poet who makes a living off her poetry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Hester Diamond’s Eldorado Duplex Is Listed for $19.5 Million
description: The apartment, on Central Park West, is where Ms. Diamond had lived with her family and her extensive collection of Modernist and old masters art.
content: For more than half a century, the art collector Hester Diamond called the imposing, twin-towered Eldorado on the Upper West Side home. It was there, in her sprawling duplex, that she put together extensive collections of Modernist and old masters works, entertained art world dignitaries and raised her family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Lauren Hirsch and Anupreeta Das
title: Inside Elon Musk’s Big Plans for Twitter
description: Here’s what Mr. Musk is projecting for Twitter’s finances over the next few years, according to a pitch deck he presented to investors.
content: Elon Musk has never been accused of dreaming small. He has reinvented at least two industries with Tesla, his electronic vehicle company, and SpaceX, the rocket company — and now his ambitions are carrying over to his $44 billion acquisition of Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: Hotel Explosion in Cuba Leaves 22 Dead
description: A blast caused by an apparent gas leak left dozens injured and destroyed parts of a luxury hotel in Havana. Others were possibly trapped inside the rubble.
content: MEXICO CITY — A powerful explosion rocked central Havana on Friday morning, destroying parts of a luxury hotel and damaging nearby buildings just yards from the Cuban Capitol building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Peter Moore, a Force in the 1980s Sneaker Revolution, Dies at 78
description: He was a key member of the team at Nike that changed sneaker culture by developing the enduringly popular Air Jordan.
content: Peter Moore, who helped revolutionize sneaker culture in the mid-1980s with his design of the remarkably popular Nike Air Jordan, died on April 29 in Portland, Ore. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: For Canelo-Bivol, DAZN Pivots to Pay-Per-View
description: Facing an eight-figure guarantee for Canelo Álvarez’s bout against Dmitry Bivol on Saturday, the streaming platform opted to charge subscribers an additional fee.
content: LAS VEGAS — At their final news conference on Thursday, Saul Álvarez, known as Canelo, glared up at Dmitry Bivol, who was posed for a routine prefight photo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman and Salamishah Tillet
title: The Multi-Layered Movie of American Fashion
description: Nine film directors, from Scorsese to Regina King to Chloé Zhao, team up with curators at the Met to reframe our country’s history of design.
content: When “In America: A Lexicon of Fashion,” the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute show, opened last September as the world first adjusted to the idea of living with Covid-19, it signaled a fresh start by reframing the dialogue around homegrown design. Now its more sprawling, multi-layered successor, “In America: An Anthology of Fashion,” takes the argument out of the basement and into the museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Medina Spirit Was Pulled by the Forelegs Into a World That Let Him Down
description: The little colt with the star on his forehead shocked the world a year ago by winning the Kentucky Derby. Those who knew and loved him still mourn what happened after that.
content: GEORGETOWN, Ky. — The rain pelted the headstone, leaving streaks on the black marble and mirroring the misty eyes of the 100 or so admirers who had come to say goodbye. None of them knew the deceased well. Many had seen him only on television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: In a seismic election shift in Northern Ireland, the pro-unity Sinn Fein is winning.
description: Final results should be available by Saturday. Some fear it could rekindle unrest between Catholics and Protestants.
content: LONDON — Northern Ireland was created a century ago, in the wake of a nationalist uprising, to protect the rights of its predominantly Protestant, pro-British population. But on Friday, the largest Irish nationalist party, Sinn Fein, was on the cusp of being declared the territory’s largest party, a political watershed in a land long torn by sectarian violence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Depp Case Brings Stan Culture Into the Courtroom and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Global Studies Tie Covid to Erectile Dysfunction
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, May 6, 2022.
content: “Communicating that the disease can affect your sexual life is a tremendously powerful message. The evidence is very strong.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: She Ran an Abortion Clinic Before Roe v. Wade. She Has Some Thoughts.
description: Merle Hoffman was on the front lines in the early 1970s, when women would travel to New York for abortions.
content: In 1970, three years before the Supreme Court’s decision in Roe v. Wade, four states, New York among them, repealed their anti-abortion statutes. At the time, Merle Hoffman was a concert pianist who had recently given up her professional ambitions. The world of classical music was too hermetic, but the sweeping political currents of the ’60s had not drawn her in either. She settled on graduate school in psychology, supporting herself with three jobs, one of them in the office of a doctor who wanted to open an abortion clinic and asked her to run it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: How the Supreme Court Became ‘Intoxicated With Its Power’
description: Three lawyers discuss what the leak says about the politics of the Supreme Court — and predict where we may go from here.
content: One of the questions haunting the unprecedented leak of Justice Samuel Alito’s draft opinion on Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization is, quite simply, who did it and why? Speculation abounds online, and Chief Justice John Roberts, who called the leak a “betrayal,” has called for an investigation. But there are other lessons to be learned from the leak — about the state of the Supreme Court and its power, its relationship with the public and the kinds of reforms it may need.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Day In the Life of the Ballet Dancer and Choreographer James Whiteside’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the daily tasks of a professional dancer. Then, students will create their own “day in the life” piece.
content: This lesson is a part of our Accessible Activities feature, which aims to welcome a wider variety of learners to our site and to The Times in general. Learn more and tell us what you think here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Unemployment Is Low. That Doesn’t Mean the Economy Is Fine.
description: Recessions begin when the jobless rate is low.
content: The Federal Reserve chair, Jerome Powell, was correct on Wednesday when he said in a news conference that the unemployment rate is “just about as low as it’s been in 50 years.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Biden’s Unpopularity
description: Covid helps explain it.
content: Shortly after taking office, President Biden called on the government to do better. “We have to prove democracy still works,” he told Congress. “That our government still works — and we can deliver for our people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: I’m Pro-Choice. But I Don’t Think Pro-Lifers Are Bad People.
description: Too often, we fail to credit our political opponents’ morality.
content: One year, when I was a graduate student, I ate twice a day with a group of other students that included about a half-dozen Republican law students. What I learned that year informs my take on the looming overturning of Roe v. Wade by the Supreme Court — assuming something close to the draft of Justice Samuel Alito’s opinion, leaked to Politico, becomes final — affecting my reaction to it, despite remaining pro-choice and being, in the grand scheme of things, alarmed by the impending developments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Can Covid Lead to Erectile Dysfunction?
description: Some studies find higher rates of erectile dysfunction among men recovering from the illness.
content: Hundreds of papers by scientists in Europe and North America, as well as in Egypt, Turkey, Iran and Thailand, point to yes. But the estimates of the magnitude of the problem vary wildly, my colleague Roni Caryn Rabin reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: The White House, warning of a fall surge, plans for how to provide vaccines if there’s no more Covid aid.
description: The White House has been asking Congress for $22.5 billion in emergency aid to continue responding to the pandemic, but Republicans have insisted on a much lower number.
content: The White House is stepping up its warnings about a coronavirus surge this fall and winter, and is making contingency plans for how it will provide vaccines to the American public if Congress does not allocate more money for the Covid-19 response, according to a senior administration official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Hawgood
title: Kid Krono Wrote Music for Kanye West Between Classes
description: Konrad Birgisson, a teenager from New York, messaged his favorite music producers on Instagram.
content: Name: Konrad Birgisson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Rogers
title: Making Up for Lost Time as Ibiza’s Clubs Reopen
description: After more than two years of pandemic-mandated uncertainty, Europe’s nightlife industry is hoping for a return to the days before Covid-19.
content: IBIZA, Spain — As the sun was setting over Ibiza last Saturday, the party at Ushuaïa was just hitting its stride. Nearly 8,000 people had gathered at the outdoor mega-club for the beginning of the island’s first clubbing season in three years, and the crowd — including many women in tasseled bikinis and tanned, musclebound men — seemed intent on making up for lost time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Lauren Halsey Brings Her Vision of South Central Los Angeles to New York
description: The artist’s solo show, which opened Friday at David Kordansky’s new Chelsea gallery, honors and documents her neighborhood.
content: Just about every day around dawn, the artist Lauren Halsey heads out into South Central Los Angeles to collect things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik
title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: U.K. Police Reopen Lockdown Inquiry Into Labour Leader
description: The police are taking another look at allegations that Keir Starmer drank beer in a lawmaker’s office, potentially subjecting him to political headaches similar to those suffered by Boris Johnson.
content: LONDON — The scandal engulfing Prime Minister Boris Johnson over lockdown-breaking parties took a twist on Friday when the British police decided to reopen an investigation into whether his political rival, Keir Starmer, the leader of the opposition Labour Party, had also broken coronavirus rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alison Block
title: Why I Learned to Perform Second-Trimester Abortions for a Post-Roe America
description: On training to provide second-trimester procedures.
content: For almost a decade as a family doctor in California, I have provided first-trimester abortions and trained family medicine residents to do the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘The Takedown’ Review: Mismatched Detectives on the Case
description: This film from Louis Leterrier tries to pay tribute to classic 1980s buddy-cop movies, but not even Omar Sy can’t salvage it.
content: Ousmane Diakité and François Monge may be French, but they will be instantly familiar to American audiences: mismatched detectives thrown together by a case, they bicker all the time, only to eventually grudgingly broker a truce. They complement each other, you see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Belarus sentences the Russian law student who was a dissident’s girlfriend to six years in prison.
description: Sofia Sapega was traveling from Greece to Lithuania with her romantic partner, Roman Protasevich, when the Belarusian air traffic control diverted their plane to Minsk, where they were both arrested.
content: A court in Belarus on Friday sentenced a Russian law student whose boyfriend is a prominent dissident to six years in a penal colony, nearly a year after the country’s authorities diverted a commercial flight to Minsk in order to arrest them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: After Soul Searching, the City of Angels and a New Mate
description: About a decade after divorcing his wife, Eric Kugler moved to Los Angeles, where he started a new relationship with Judge Dean Hansell and, later, a second career.
content: Eric Kugler likes to say he met Judge Dean Hansell through Ed Sullivan and Ingrid Bergman. What actually brought them together in February 2011, though, was GLAAD, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: The Winner of Modern Love’s College Essay Contest
description: The results of our sixth college contest are in!
content: This February, Modern Love opened its sixth college essay contest, asking college students nationwide to tell the truth about love today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Season 2, Episode 10 Recap: Q’s Last Gift
description: The “Picard” crew tries to find its way home.
content: So after all that, all the Jurati-Borg Queen combination had to do was show up earlier and none of the this season’s craziness would’ve happened?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: The War Is Getting More Dangerous for America, and Biden Knows It
description: Leaks by U.S. officials suggest we are no longer in an indirect war with Russia but rather edging toward a direct one.
content: If you just followed news reports on Ukraine, you might think that the war has settled into a long, grinding and somewhat boring slog. You would be wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: C.D.C. Is Investigating 109 Cases of Hepatitis in Children, Including 5 Deaths
description: The agency stressed that the disease was still very rare in children and that a cause had not been determined.
content: The deaths of five children and what may be an unusual group of more than 100 hepatitis cases in young children in the United States are under investigation by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the agency said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Donald Trump Didn’t Hijack the G.O.P. He Understood It.
description: Matthew Continetti traces the hidden populist history of the American right.
content: Right now, Republicans of all stripes — Ron DeSantis, J.D. Vance, Mike Pence, Glenn Youngkin — are trying to figure out how to channel the populist energies of Donald Trump into a winning political message. The struggle to achieve such a synthesis is the defining project on the American right today. Its outcome will determine the future of the Republican Party — and American politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: M15 Spies With One Thing in Common: They’ve Screwed Up
description: In “Bad Actors,” Mick Herron’s latest Slough House novel, a group of maladroit agents confronts a scandal in their own office.
content: “BAD ACTORS” (Soho Crime, 341 pp., $27.95), the newest Slough House spy novel by Mick Herron, has at last arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Utah Welcomes the Ironman World Championship. For One Time Only.
description: This weekend’s Ironman is technically the 2021 event. And it’s not in Kona.
content: The 2021 Ironman World Championship is set to take place Saturday morning in St. George, Utah. There’s a lot to unpack in that strange sentence, because just about everything going on with this event, which usually takes place in October in Kona on the Big Island of Hawaii, is a little out of sync.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Italy seizes a superyacht tied to Putin.
description: Italian police boarded the yacht, the Scheherazade, late on Friday, ending what appeared to be preparations to set sail.
content: After weeks of investigation, Italian authorities announced late Friday evening that they had impounded a nearly $700 million superyacht, saying that its owner had “significant economic and business links” to “prominent elements of the Russian government.” According to U.S. officials, the prominent element is none other than Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick
title: A grinding artillery war in Ukraine
description: Ukraine goes on the offensive against Russian forces
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah Askarinam
title: Roe’s Potential End Forces Politicians Into a Deeper Abortion Debate
description: Republicans face new pressure to define exactly where they stand on the hot-button issue, while Democrats must now fully confront a topic many have approached carefully.
content: The precedent of Roe v. Wade has often offered a shield to politicians in both parties when it comes to discussing abortion, allowing them to take up their preferred label — “pro-choice” or “pro-life” — without wading into the details.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Remembering the 1992 Los Angeles Riots
description: A reporter who covered the riots reflects 30 years later.
content: On the second day of the 1992 riots, Woodrow Wilson High in Long Beach was the scene of a terrifying event, in which “about 200 students were involved in a racially motivated brawl,” The Los Angeles Times reported at the time. The Long Beach Press-Telegram called it a “lunchtime melee,” an explosion of Southern California’s racial tensions in microcosm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: You Bought a House. Your Colleague Didn’t. It’s Still OK to Celebrate.
description: Guilt around your good fortune will not change the failures of late stage capitalism.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, the oracles of Acrostica, bring us a windswept puzzle.
content: ACROSTIC — There’s no hard and fast rule on the timing of each acrostic, unless it’s pegged to Thanksgiving or baseball’s opening day, for example. But sometimes, Team Cox/Rathvon amazes me with its timing. Today’s passage is from a 2021 historical novel by Kristin Hannah called “The Four Winds,” about a family based in Depression-era Texas. It concerns the overwhelming quantity of unseen labor performed by women on a farm and its ultimate, destructive effect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Lynsea Garrison, Jessica Cheung, Michael Simon Johnson, Clare Toeniskoetter, Liz O. Baylen, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: A Post-Roe America, Part 1: The Anti-Abortion Activists
description: What next for a movement that looks to have achieved a decades-long goal?
content: Since the leak of the Supreme Court draft opinion on overturning the constitutional right to abortion, both sides of the fight have been scrambling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: Working Best With a Minimum of Information
description: Alexandra Goodman and Christopher Masullo, who met on Tinder in 2017, share a love of celebration and Stephen Sondheim.
content: Alexandra Scott Goodman was perusing Tinder in September 2017 when the three-word bio of Christopher Nicholas Masullo, who went by his nickname Chris on the dating app, caught her eye. “Perpetually in awe,” it read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Rachel Sherman
title: Most of Broadway Ends Vaccine Checks as Cases Rise in New York
description: While for-profit theater owners and operators agreed to stop checking proof of vaccination this week, several nonprofit Broadway theaters continue to require it.
content: A man had his photo I.D. out and in his hand as walked up to the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on Broadway to see “Come From Away,” but no one checked it. The families streaming in to see “The Lion King” were told to have their tickets out and their masks on, but there was no mention of vaccine cards. And the Covid safety officers in neon yellow vests who used to patrol outside “Six” were gone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: ‘Last Ward’ Review: Ashes to Ashes, Dirt to Dirt
description: Yaa Samar! Dance Theater’s production at Gibney is an uncommonly deft combination of dance and verbal theater.
content: Picture a standard, sterile hospital room. From behind a cabinet, an arm snakes out, followed by the rest of the body — a man with serpentine moves who slinks around and creeps under the bed. Immediately, the death implicit in the setting has become visible, corporeal, though still metaphorical, in a particular way. The man suggesting death is a dancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Austin Ramzy
title: In a One-Man Race in Hong Kong, China Is Guaranteed to Win
description: John Lee, a Beijing loyalist who oversaw the crackdown on pro-democracy protests, built his career by deepening his contacts within the mainland security services.
content: HONG KONG — When hundreds of thousands of Hong Kong residents took to the streets in 2019 to protest a proposed extradition bill, John Lee, the security secretary at the time, went before the city’s Legislative Council to defend the government’s position.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Has Thoughts on the Rise in Interest Rates
description: Noah blamed inflation on “the pandemic, supply chain issues and a Russian man who clearly wasn’t hugged enough as a child.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: Fancy Fascinators and Floral Dresses
description: Socialities and philanthropists flock to the Central Park Conservancy’s annual hat luncheon.
content: “Does anyone still wear a hat?” Stephen Sondheim wrote in the song “The Ladies Who Lunch.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Let the Oven Work for You
description: Ali Slagle’s gnocchi with sweet and hot peppers is delightfully hands-off, cooking both sauce and pasta at the same time.
content: I made Ali Slagle’s gnocchi with sweet and hot peppers for dinner this week, which is one of those easy, let-the-oven-do-the-work recipes that hit just right after a long day. In that recipe, cherry tomatoes, bell peppers and canned chipotles roast in oil until they collapse into a sweet and smoky sauce for gnocchi, or really for anything you’d like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: The Dollar Is Stronger. Who Wins? Who Loses?
description: The forces unsettling the stock and bond markets — Fed rate increases, Russia’s war in Ukraine, global sanctions on Russia, China’s lockdowns — have been buoying the dollar.
content: These are rocky times for most investments. But it has been a wonderful stretch for the dollar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Before There Were Birds or Bees, This Is How Trilobites Made Babies
description: The discovery of clasper limbs in a fossil suggests that some species of the ancient arthropods reproduced much like modern horseshoe crabs.
content: The sturdy, calcite-infused exoskeletons of trilobites and their segmented shells are nearly ubiquitous in fossil deposits from the Cambrian Period to the Permian. But this trove of trilobite fossils has revealed frustratingly little when it comes to how the Paleozoic animals reproduced across 250 million years of living on ancient Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Burleigh
title: A Return Trip to Timothy Leary’s Psychedelic, Day-Glo Mexico
description: Most travelers descending on Zihuatanejo are unaware of the resort city’s storied past with the apostle of psychedelic drugs, and his experiments in consciousness expansion.
content: Everyone smiles as you drift past the flowers/ That grow so incredibly high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: G.O.P. Lawmakers Recast Abortion Stance, Wary of Voter Backlash
description: While Democrats decry a draft opinion that would eliminate the constitutional right to an abortion, Republicans who worked decades for this moment have been largely silent.
content: WASHINGTON — Republicans have spent decades attacking the landmark Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion nationwide, but with the toppling of Roe v. Wade seemingly imminent, their leaders in Congress and around the country have grown suddenly quiet on the issue, part of a bid to avoid a backlash against their party ahead of the midterm elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: New York’s Dancehall Parties Are ‘A Different Type of Turn Up’
description: From a Sean Paul show in Brooklyn to a 1,000-person yacht party on the Hudson River, the city’s dancehall fans are showing up in droves.
content: This story is part of an occasional series exploring nightlife in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Ukrainian forces regain ground from Russia.
content: Fighting raged across eastern Ukraine — from the Kharkiv area in the north, where Ukrainian forces regained ground, to Mariupol in the south, where Russian forces sought to destroy the last pocket of resistance at the Azovstal steel plant and where about 200 civilians were holed up with fighters. Follow live updates from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Customs and Border Protection Will Disband Secretive ‘Critical Incident Teams’
description: The agency’s commissioner announced the change after the teams — which had long operated under the public radar — came under scrutiny earlier this year.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration will disband secretive teams within the U.S. Border Patrol by the end of September, after their role in internal investigations came under scrutiny earlier this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Cora Engelbrecht and Michael Levenson
title: Turning Tables on Russia With West’s Arms, Ukraine Goes on Offense
description: Ukrainian forces are seeking to drive back Russian invaders from two key cities in northeast Ukraine and achieve a breakthrough in what has become a grinding battle.
content: KRAKOW, Poland — Ukrainian troops, emboldened by sophisticated weapons and long-range artillery supplied by the West, went on the offensive Friday against Russian forces in the northeast, seeking to drive them back from two key cities as the war plunged more deeply into a grinding, town-for-town battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Ghosts Hover Over a New Collaboration at City Ballet
description: The choreographer Silas Farley and the composer David K. Israel team up for “Architects of Time,” a premiere for the Stravinsky Festival.
content: It’s hard to digest New York City Ballet’s latest premiere without knowing the story behind it. In a roundabout way, it’s a story ballet, but not the kind in which a princess falls asleep after being pricked by a needle. “Architects of Time,” a collaboration between the choreographer Silas Farley and the composer David K. Israel, is a back-story ballet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Queen’s Jubilee Photo-Op: A Slimmed-Down Royal Family
description: Neither Prince Harry and his wife Meghan, nor Prince Andrew will get a place on the balcony at Buckingham Palace. It’s not even certain Queen Elizabeth, 96, will be there.
content: LONDON — When Queen Elizabeth II kicks off the Platinum Jubilee, celebrating 70 years on the British throne, next month, she will do so with a slimmed-down royal family behind her: Neither Prince Harry and his wife Meghan, nor Prince Andrew will get a place on the balcony at Buckingham Palace to wave at the crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A federal judge dismisses Trump’s lawsuit seeking to reinstate his Twitter account.
description: The former president sued Twitter after it permanently blocked his account in the wake of the Capitol riot.
content: A federal judge in San Francisco on Friday dismissed former President Donald J. Trump’s lawsuit against Twitter over the social media company’s decision to bar him from its platform permanently after the Jan. 6 attack at the U.S. Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Death of Roe Is Going to Tear America Apart
description: You think we hate each other now? Just wait.
content: In his draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, Justice Samuel Alito blamed that 1973 abortion decision for sparking “a national controversy that has embittered our political culture for a half century.” He quoted Justice Antonin Scalia: “Roe fanned into life an issue that has inflamed our national politics in general, and has obscured with its smoke the selection of justices to this court in particular, ever since.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Borrowing From ‘The Natural,’ Ohtani Makes an Impression at Fenway
description: The Angels’ two-way star dominated on the mound and knocked his own number off the scoreboard with a line drive. All in a day’s work.
content: It sure was clever in “The Natural” when Roy Hobbs belted the ball into the stadium clock, smashing it. A great moment in a fanciful story.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Matthew Continetti
description: A conversation with journalist Matthew Continetti.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Matt Continetti. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: New in Paperback: ‘The Love Songs of W.E.B. Du Bois’ and ‘Bloodlands’
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
content: THE LOVE SONGS OF W. E. B. DU BOIS, by Honorée Fanonne Jeffers. (Harper Perennial, 816 pp., $20.) This debut novel, one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2021, tells the converging stories of a Black girl growing up at the end of the 20th century and the “songs” of her Native American and enslaved African American ancestors. Our reviewer, Veronica Chambers, wrote that it was “quite simply the best book that I have read in a very, very long time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Mets Erase Six-Run Deficit in Ninth to Beat Phillies
description: Starling Marte’s R.B.I. double capped a huge rally and gave the Mets an unlikely win against a division rival.
content: PHILADELPHIA — The previous 330 times the Mets trailed by six runs in the ninth inning, they had lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: In Georgia, a judge rules that Marjorie Taylor Greene did not engage in an insurrection on Jan. 6.
description: A Georgia administrative law judge said Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican seeking a second term, should remain on the ballot.
content: An administrative law judge found on Friday that Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene should be eligible to run for re-election, saying that he saw no evidence the Georgia Republican engaged in an insurrection on Jan. 6, as several legal challengers had asserted in an effort to have her removed from the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Frank Langella Blames ‘Cancel Culture’ After Firing From Netflix Show
description: The actor said his dismissal from “The Fall of the House of Usher” followed a love scene in which the actress playing his wife accused him of touching her leg.
content: Frank Langella, who was fired in April from his leading role in a Netflix mini-series after a misconduct investigation, said on Thursday that his dismissal followed a love scene in which the actress playing his wife accused him of touching her leg — an action not in the script.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Renaud Philippe
title: A Fight Over America’s Energy Future Erupts on the Canadian Border
description: Power companies, conservationists, local residents and two U.S. states are mired in an acrimonious dispute about hydroelectricity from Quebec.
content: RADISSON, Quebec — Hundreds of feet below a remote forest near Hudson Bay, Serge Abergel inspected the spinning turbines at the heart of the biggest subterranean power plant in the world, a massive facility that converts the water of the La Grande River into a current of renewable electricity strong enough to power a midsize city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Giuliani Pulls Out of Interview With Jan. 6 Committee
description: The former personal lawyer to Donald J. Trump withdrew from an interview scheduled for Friday after the panel would not let him record it, his lawyer said.
content: WASHINGTON — Rudolph W. Giuliani, who helped lead President Donald J. Trump’s effort to overturn the results of the 2020 election as his personal lawyer, on Thursday abruptly pulled out of a scheduled Friday interview with the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol after the panel refused to let him record the session.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Guantánamo Detainee Refuses to Testify for Accused U.S.S. Cole Bomber
description: Defense lawyers wanted a deposition from a Yemeni detainee who has been cleared for release, but the detainee said he feared his testimony would be used against him.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A Yemeni prisoner at Guantánamo Bay who was cleared for release nearly a year ago scolded an Army judge on Friday and refused to testify in the U.S.S. Cole bombing case, fearing he would place himself in jeopardy after 20 years of U.S. detention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson and His Party Suffer Setbacks in Local Voting in Britain
description: But the British leader appeared to have survived the storm — for now at least — as the head of the opposition Labour Party came under scrutiny for violating lockdown rules himself.
content: LONDON — Embroiled in a sprawling scandal over parties in Downing Street that broke lockdown rules, Britain’s prime minister, Boris Johnson, suffered a succession of setbacks on Friday in local elections as voters across the country abandoned his Conservative Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: America Is Not Ready for the End of Roe v. Wade
description: Americans are about to lose a constitutional right. It’s worth fighting for.
content: Imagine that every state were free to choose whether to allow Black people and white people to marry. Some states would permit such marriages; others probably wouldn’t. The laws would be a mishmash, and interracial couples would suffer, legally consigned to second-class status depending on where they lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Fuchs
title: V.R. ‘Reminiscence Therapy’ Lets Seniors Relive the Past
description: Some care facilities are giving older adults a way to visit their pasts to boost their well-being.
content: John Faulkner, 76, was becoming emotionally withdrawn before he arrived at Central Parke Assisted Living and Memory Care, the community where he lives in Mason, Ohio. He had once been an avid traveler, but cognitive decline ended that, and he became socially isolated. By the time Mr. Faulkner arrived at Central Parke, he would sit alone in his room for hours, according to Esther Mwilu, who organizes activities for the community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: A federal court clears the way for Florida’s restrictive voting law.
description: The appeals court said a lower court order blocking parts of the law had been issued too close to the state’s primary elections this summer.
content: A federal appeals court cleared the way on Friday for a restrictive new voting law in Florida to take effect, saying that a lower court order blocking parts of the law had been issued too close to the state’s scheduled primary elections in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: American Bar Association May Eliminate Standardized Tests for Admissions
description: A committee within the A.B.A. has recommended that law schools stop requiring standardized tests like the LSAT as part of their admissions process.
content: No more LSATs?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
description: The Supreme Court leak was top of mind for the late-night hosts, as was inflation and a flub made by former President Donald Trump.
content: The Supreme Court leak was top of mind for the late-night hosts, as was inflation and a flub made by former President Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: The War in Ukraine, as Seen on Russian TV
description: According to Russian news media, the worst atrocities in Ukraine are staged. We analyzed more than 50 hours of television to show Russia’s version of events.
content: According to Russian news media, the worst atrocities in Ukraine are staged. We analyzed more than 50 hours of television to show Russia’s version of events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Dowling
title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Selections from the Weekend section, including an interview with Bad Bunny.
content: Selections from the Weekend section, including an interview with Bad Bunny.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The New York Times News Quiz, May 6, 2022
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
content: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Rayfield
title: The Weekender
description: The climate profit of Scotland’s peat bogs. Also in this edition: a chat with Cate Blanchett and Cindy Sherman, and a “Golden Girls” convention.
content: The climate profit of Scotland’s peat bogs. Also in this edition: a chat with Cate Blanchett and Cindy Sherman, and a “Golden Girls” convention.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Where a Love of Art Can Take You
description: The collector Hester Diamond’s duplex at the Eldorado is listed for $19.5 million.
content: The collector Hester Diamond’s duplex at the Eldorado is listed for $19.5 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Extreme Weather Batters the South and Midwest
description: Springtime storms brought tornadoes, floods and hail to states across the South and Midwest. In Texas and Oklahoma, tornadoes tore the roof off a school and caused damage to homes and businesses.
content: Springtime storms brought tornadoes, floods and hail to states across the South and Midwest. In Texas and Oklahoma, tornadoes tore the roof off a school and caused damage to homes and businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Disastrous Poetry and Other Letters to the Editor
description: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Recipes for Mother’s Day, a deep dive into a San Francisco classic stew and more.
content: Good morning. Tejal Rao has an exciting piece of restaurant criticism in The Times this week, about finding great cioppino in San Francisco, a city so awash in the seafood stew that it can sometimes appear cliché.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Abortion Case: A ‘Spurious’ Argument and ‘Clear Bias’
description: Readers raise questions about the constitutional reasoning and Catholic influence in the leaked draft ruling. Also: Preventing addiction; access to parks.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
